author: tmdrtn
title: Toddler train era has begun!
review:
being a fan of Lego trains (in particular 12V) I just had to buy my daughter a Duplo train. Being little under two years maybe a bit to early, but sha manages really well with some help which is allot of fun

Box/Instructions

Super simple instructions, but some stepwise instructions are included, the box is big and attractive to pick off the shelf in the toystore.

Parts

Nice quality, many printed parts, no stickers on Duplo, which toddlers offcourse cannot manage, I love the classic look of the steam locomotive and the sound of adding water into the kettle, the wistle and of the steamcilinders, very nice, something which should be included in todays Lego train line-up.

Minifigures

Two, a machinist for the locomotive and a young female passenger with suitcase, nice sturdy quality

The build

Easy and fast with help from dad!

The completed model

Allot of fun to play with, looks and feels very sturdy.

Overall opinion

Spot-on for us, 5 stars!

author: morvit
title: Great little set!
review:
My girlfriend bought this for her nephew (who is 2 and a half years old) a while back and I must say I'm impressed. This set is packed with fun features. These include a fully functional and good-looking train with sound (kids love this). Just insert 3 AA batteries into the train and press the button on the top of the first cart and the train will move forward while making train sounds.

There is also a gas pump that you can plug into the train and sounds will come out from the train! There is also enough rail for a circle (even if the train operates outside of the rail, kids still love to have the train going forward and hitting the wall). 2 mini-figures and an animal are included (always good to have these as these are always a hit with kids, not just adults) as well, which is quite a reasonable amount for the price. Finally, the bricks included here are above-average for a Duplo set as it creates a good-looking house-like structure (with window, roof and a clock) that the train can pass through. All in all, for USD 45, there is a lot of great features here. We have bought her nephew other Duplo sets before, but this is by far her nephew's favorite now. 

I also own the Lego cargo train myself (60052) that I paid around USD 150 for (and I'm pretty happy with that set). If I compare the 2 though, I feel that if one can get 3 of this type of Duplo set (a short train with railways, with decent amount of minifigures and bricks at a 45 dollar price point) and have the rail connected (maybe add some switching tracks so the 3 trains can run simultaneously), the Duplo train could be even more impressive as a stand-alone unit than the 60052.
